**TERRITORIAL NEWS**

*From the Leader, Oct. 4.*

Eighty-three fires burned last week. The atmosphere was thick with smoke on Saturday night, beginning near the proximity of Prairie House.

Indications are good and the large number of buildings going up indicate that Regina, like the Leader, is flourishing.

A gang of thieves, consisting of Mr. W. Macdonald and an employee of contractor Mclean left last week for Wood Mountain where they will soon be heard from.

This has been a season of mammals equalling the North-West as well as Manitoba. We expect that the vegeta- tive shows more than ever before to old residents of the Territories.

A correspondent writing from Wapella says: "On Saturday the 24th, about 11 a.m., a party of three white men, armed with revolvers, came into the brigantine settlement, its course being N.E. by S.W. They approached with intent to rob the settlers of their wagons and stores. When seen our party were 15 miles south of Elkhorn. Should any young man be interested in this affair, he will perhaps say where they saw it."

**EDMONTON**

*From the Bulletin, Sept. 17.*

W. Humbertson burned 80,000 bricks this season.

Fred Halland and Sons have secured a five years lease of the privilege of mining coal under the McLennan estate in the hands of Messrs. Macdonald and Co.

There is talk of raising a new apple hall in Edmonton this fall or winter. A Macdonald & Co. have offered a lot for that purpose but the project has not yet taken definite shape.

Monday was rainy and a few snowflakes fell. The first snowstorm of the season occurred on Tuesday night. A hailstorm, which wound up vegetable growth for the season, struck in the same way, causing damage to crops. Later came the first heavy frost which marks the line between summer and fall occurred on Sept. 29.

J. C. Cassel, H. R. chief factor in charge of Macdonald river district, with his family, including chief factor's son-in-law, Mr. Douglas, chief factor's daughter-in-law, Mrs. Douglas, and C.F. Gaudet in charge of Fort Good Hope, Mr. Gaudet's wife and children, arrived from Winnipeg on Thursday last. They leave for the north to morrow, accompanied by Dr. McKay of Peace River district, who is returning from a visit to England and will be met at Fort Chipewyan.

**BATTLEFORD**

*From the Herald Oct. 1.*

The threshers are all busy, and the fields fully equal the most sanguine expectations.

Archdeacon J. A. M. Kay and the Rev. J. Wright, both of Prince Albert, visited this place on Friday morning.

Dr. Thomas, who has been engaged with the Prince Albert, Masters James Johnston and John Wright went down to Battleford on Friday afternoon.

Long Dalhousie, who visited the community in the lock-up here for having two free men sign signatures without backs, is now back in town.

Cardinal Taschereau has declined the offer of the Quebec chateau as temporary residence.

**CALGARY**

*From the Tribune Oct. 7.*

George Brown, left on Wednesday for New Westminster, B.C., will arrive there next week.

SEED GRAIN.

The following good news is in a copy of a letter received at the local Dominion Land office, and which will be read with interest by every farmer.

Office of the D. L. Commissioner,
Winnipeg, 4 Oct. 1887.

Sir,—I am directed to request you to forward a copy of the Prince Albert newspaper that appeared yesterday, in order that the Minister of Interior may endeavor to secure the release of the seed grain which was held up by the government pending the decision on this question. We are authorized to accept the seed for deposit on account, and to issue a formal receipt hereafter.

I have the honor etc.,
(Signed) F. R. Burge.

General News.

Montreal, Oct. 9.—Senator Murray, the minister of the interior, has been requested to take steps for improving the railway system, and is expected to do so throughout the province.

Toronto, Oct. 9.—Cardinal Taschereau died at government house last night, and laid the cornerstone of St. Paul's church in Ottawa on Friday evening.

Montreal, Oct. 9.—Four young men performed the feat of running the fastest marathon distance this afternoon. This has never been done before to human knowledge.

Montreal, Oct. 9.—Mr. Craig Bayley, secretary of McGill college, made very notable this morning, age 75.

Quebec, Oct. 9.—A disastrous fire occurred at St. Philippe, Kamouraska, a few days ago. The fire started from a broken oil lamp, caused St. Jean, warned by the panic, to rush to the scene and put out the fire. The fire was extinguished there with the help of neighboring towns. He was assisted by a number of volunteers, who came to assist during the fire. The fire destroyed a number of houses and the main streets of the town.

Montreal, Oct. 9.—Mr. J. M. Campbell, Pacific traffic manager, denies the telegraphed statement that the company has abandoned its plans to build a new line. An official statement just arrived. It appears that 40,000 tons of wheat have been shipped from Montreal to points during the past week, and 200 cars have been ordered for traffic, while 300 cars were on hand to supply them.

Montreal, Oct. 9.—There has been another hitch connected with the fire, and a half million loan which Premier Macdonald promised to raise for the fire department, has been delayed. It is difficult to understand what is the matter, but the trouble has been removed.

Montreal, Oct. 9.—Hon. Mr. Chapleau, who returned from Europe Saturday, has no intention of accepting the governorship of Quebec and appears of Sir John A. Macdonald to participate in Mercier's election contest.

Montreal, Oct. 9.—Railroad officials of the French Chamber of commerce have decided to send a delegation to the government to protest against the proposed legislation, having a tendency to reduce the value of local currency.

Gatineau, Oct. 9.—A very severe storm occurred at a height of two thousand feet, and was caused by a hailstorm. The hail was caused by a hot air current, and the hailstones fell twenty-eight feet in diameter. The descent was a magnificent sight, the hailstones striking the ground like bullets. Attenay struck the ground very lightly and remained standing.

Seattle, W. T., Oct. 9.—L. H. Shaw, a prominent citizen, has been taken into custody on complaint of his wife. He is charged with maintaining a common lodging-house for women, aged 14. The crime was first perpetrated when the child was 12 years of age. The case is all the details being investigated and will be heard in court. Shaw remains in jail.

J. M. Campbell
